subject: Communication
title: The Cocktail Party Effect
description: A quick win: understand The Cocktail Party Effect.

hook.text: A crowded room. Fifty conversations at once. Someone across the room says your name. You hear it instantly. How?

buildup.text: Colin Cherry discovered the 'cocktail party effect' in 1953: the brain can selectively attend to one voice among many.

twist.text: The unattended conversations aren't gone. Your brain monitors them at low level â€” which is how your name breaks.

climax.text: The cocktail party effect reveals that listening is fundamentally about selection.

punchline.text: Your brain is always listening. It just decides what deserves your attention.
